comment_text.mn29:1.2: Devadatta was the Buddha’s cousin and nemesis. After going forth together with several other relatives of the Buddha (Kd 17:1.4.1), his initial success in meditation was corrupted by his desire for gains and fame (SN 17.35). He tried to take over the Saṅgha but was denounced by the Buddha. His attempt to create a schismatic faction failed and he died in disgrace.
comment_text.mn29:2.8: The Chinese parallel at EA 43.4 says that this discourse was given during the time he was being lavishly supported by Prince Ajātasattu (SN 17.36, Kd 17:2.1.1).
comment_text.mn29:2.9: Compare the “noble quest” on MN 26 and the search for a “bull elephant” in MN 27. In each case the metaphor emphasizes the specific and uncompromising nature of the goal. The moral is to not stop until the journey is truly complete.
comment_text.mn29:5.14: While “knowledge and vision” (ñāṇadassana) that is “in accordance with reality” (yathābhūta) refers to the vision of the four noble truths at stream-entry, “knowledge and vision” by itself does not have a well established technical meaning. At DN 2:83.1 it is said to be a vision of the body with its consciousness, although this passage is rare and in MN 77:29.11 is not described as “knowledge and vision”. Elsewhere it is used in a variety of senses for a kind of clear and enhanced spiritual understanding.
comment_text.mn29:6.16: The “irreversible freedom” (asamaya, literally “not temporary”) is that of arahantship, as opposed to the “temporary freedom” of samādhi, from which one can fall away due to bad conduct (AN 5.149), like Devadatta. | Text inconsistently has vimokkha (“liberation”) here and vimutti (“freedom”) in the next line, although elsewhere the suttas always read vimutti. It seems that when these attainments came to be included in the Vimokkha Chapter of the Paṭisambhidāmagga (a late canonical Abhidhamma-style text), they were renamed vimokkha to fit the context (Ps 1.5:2.10). The commentary then cited that passage here using vimokkha, but the commentarial gloss must have contaminated the text. I translate under the assumption that the correct reading is vimutti, although it makes no practical difference.
comment_text.mn29:7.2: This links the “irreversible” freedom with the “unshakable” freedom of arahantship; the two are equated at MN 122:4.1.

root_text.mn29:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
root_text.mn29:1.3: Tatra kho bhagavā devadattaṁ ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.mn29:2.1: “Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:2.2: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:2.3: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:2.4: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:2.5: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:2.6: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attānukkaṁseti paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:2.7: ‘ahamasmi lābhasakkārasilokavā, ime panaññe bhikkhū appaññātā appesakkhā’ti.
root_text.mn29:2.8: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:2.9: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṁ atikkamma phegguṁ atikkamma tacaṁ atikkamma papaṭikaṁ, sākhāpalāsaṁ chetvā ādāya pakkameyya ‘sāran’ti maññamāno.
root_text.mn29:2.10: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn29:2.11: ‘na vatāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso aññāsi sāraṁ, na aññāsi phegguṁ, na aññāsi tacaṁ, na aññāsi papaṭikaṁ, na aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṁ.
root_text.mn29:2.12: Tathā hayaṁ bhavaṁ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṁ atikkamma phegguṁ atikkamma tacaṁ atikkamma papaṭikaṁ, sākhāpalāsaṁ chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti maññamāno.
root_text.mn29:2.13: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṁ tañcassa atthaṁ nānubhavissatī’ti.
root_text.mn29:2.14: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:2.15: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:2.16: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:2.17: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:2.18: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:2.19: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti ‘ahamasmi lābhasakkārasilokavā, ime panaññe bhikkhū appaññātā appesakkhā’ti.
root_text.mn29:2.20: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:2.21: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sākhāpalāsaṁ aggahesi brahmacariyassa;
root_text.mn29:3.1: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:3.2: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:3.3: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:3.4: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:3.5: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:3.6: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:3.7: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn29:3.9: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:3.10: So tāya sīlasampadāya attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:3.11: ‘ahamasmi sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo, ime panaññe bhikkhū dussīlā pāpadhammā’ti.
root_text.mn29:3.12: So tāya sīlasampadāya majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:3.13: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṁ atikkamma phegguṁ atikkamma tacaṁ, papaṭikaṁ chetvā ādāya pakkameyya ‘sāran’ti maññamāno.
root_text.mn29:3.14: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn29:3.15: ‘na vatāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso aññāsi sāraṁ, na aññāsi phegguṁ, na aññāsi tacaṁ, na aññāsi papaṭikaṁ, na aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṁ.
root_text.mn29:3.16: Tathā hayaṁ bhavaṁ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṁ atikkamma phegguṁ atikkamma tacaṁ, papaṭikaṁ chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti maññamāno;
root_text.mn29:3.17: yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṁ tañcassa atthaṁ nānubhavissatī’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.1: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:4.2: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:4.3: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.

root_text.mn29:4.5: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.6: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:4.7: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn29:4.9: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.10: So tāya sīlasampadāya attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:4.11: ‘ahamasmi sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo, ime panaññe bhikkhū dussīlā pāpadhammā’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.12: So tāya sīlasampadāya majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:4.13: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu papaṭikaṁ aggahesi brahmacariyassa;
root_text.mn29:4.15: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:4.16: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:4.17: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.18: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:4.19: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.20: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:4.21: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:4.22: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.23: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:4.24: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn29:4.26: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.27: So tāya samādhisampadāya attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:4.28: ‘ahamasmi samāhito ekaggacitto, ime panaññe bhikkhū asamāhitā vibbhantacittā’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.29: So tāya samādhisampadāya majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:4.30: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṁ atikkamma phegguṁ tacaṁ chetvā ādāya pakkameyya ‘sāran’ti maññamāno.
root_text.mn29:4.31: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya ‘na vatāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso aññāsi sāraṁ, na aññāsi phegguṁ, na aññāsi tacaṁ, na aññāsi papaṭikaṁ, na aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṁ.
root_text.mn29:4.32: Tathā hayaṁ bhavaṁ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṁ atikkamma phegguṁ tacaṁ chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti maññamāno.
root_text.mn29:4.33: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṁ tañcassa atthaṁ nānubhavissatī’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.34: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:4.35: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:4.36: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.37: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:4.38: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.39: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:4.40: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:4.41: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.42: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:4.43: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:4.44: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:4.45: So tāya samādhisampadāya attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:4.46: ‘ahamasmi samāhito ekaggacitto, ime panaññe bhikkhū asamāhitā vibbhantacittā’ti.
root_text.mn29:4.47: So tāya samādhisampadāya majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:4.48: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tacaṁ aggahesi brahmacariyassa;

root_text.mn29:5.3: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.

root_text.mn29:5.6: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:5.7: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn29:5.9: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:5.10: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:5.11: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:5.12: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:5.13: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:5.14: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:5.15: So tena ñāṇadassanena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:5.16: So tena ñāṇadassanena attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:5.18: Ime panaññe bhikkhū ajānaṁ apassaṁ viharantī’ti.
root_text.mn29:5.19: So tena ñāṇadassanena majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.

root_text.mn29:5.22: ‘na vatāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso aññāsi sāraṁ na aññāsi phegguṁ na aññāsi tacaṁ na aññāsi papaṭikaṁ na aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṁ.

root_text.mn29:5.24: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṁ tañcassa atthaṁ nānubhavissatī’ti.
root_text.mn29:5.25: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:5.26: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:5.27: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:5.28: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:5.29: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:5.30: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:5.31: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:5.32: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:5.33: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:5.34: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:5.35: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:5.36: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:5.37: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṁ ārādheti.

root_text.mn29:5.39: So tena ñāṇadassanena attānukkaṁseti, paraṁ vambheti:
root_text.mn29:5.40: ‘ahamasmi jānaṁ passaṁ viharāmi, ime panaññe bhikkhū ajānaṁ apassaṁ viharantī’ti.
root_text.mn29:5.41: So tena ñāṇadassanena majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn29:5.42: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu phegguṁ aggahesi brahmacariyassa;

root_text.mn29:6.8: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.9: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.10: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.11: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.12: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.13: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.14: So tena ñāṇadassanena attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.15: So tena ñāṇadassanena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.16: So tena ñāṇadassanena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno asamayavimokkhaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.17: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, bhikkhave, anavakāso yaṁ so bhikkhu tāya asamayavimuttiyā parihāyetha.
root_text.mn29:6.18: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato sāraññeva chetvā ādāya pakkameyya ‘sāran’ti jānamāno.
root_text.mn29:6.19: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn29:6.20: ‘aññāsi vatāyaṁ bhavaṁ puriso sāraṁ, aññāsi phegguṁ, aññāsi tacaṁ, aññāsi papaṭikaṁ, aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṁ.
root_text.mn29:6.21: Tathā hayaṁ bhavaṁ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṁ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato sāraññeva chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti jānamāno.
root_text.mn29:6.22: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṁ tañcassa atthaṁ anubhavissatī’ti.
root_text.mn29:6.23: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn29:6.24: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
root_text.mn29:6.25: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn29:6.26: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṁ abhinibbatteti.
root_text.mn29:6.27: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti, na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.28: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.29: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.30: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.31: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.32: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.33: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.34: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.35: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.36: So tena ñāṇadassanena attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
root_text.mn29:6.37: So tena ñāṇadassanena na attānukkaṁseti, na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.mn29:6.38: So tena ñāṇadassanena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṁ āpajjati, appamatto samāno asamayavimokkhaṁ ārādheti.
root_text.mn29:6.39: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, bhikkhave, anavakāso yaṁ so bhikkhu tāya asamayavimuttiyā parihāyetha.
root_text.mn29:7.1: Iti kho, bhikkhave, nayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ lābhasakkārasilokānisaṁsaṁ, na sīlasampadānisaṁsaṁ, na samādhisampadānisaṁsaṁ, na ñāṇadassanānisaṁsaṁ.
root_text.mn29:7.2: Yā ca kho ayaṁ, bhikkhave, akuppā cetovimutti—
root_text.mn29:7.3: etadatthamidaṁ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṁ, etaṁ sāraṁ etaṁ pariyosānan”ti.
root_text.mn29:7.5: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn29:0.2: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood
translation_text.mn29:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
translation_text.mn29:1.3: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
translation_text.mn29:2.1: “Mendicants, take the case of a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
translation_text.mn29:2.2: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn29:2.3: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
translation_text.mn29:2.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
translation_text.mn29:2.5: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:2.6: And they glorify themselves and put others down because of that:
translation_text.mn29:2.7: ‘I’m the one with possessions, honor, and popularity. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’
translation_text.mn29:2.8: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.
translation_text.mn29:2.9: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and leave imagining they were heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:2.10: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
translation_text.mn29:2.11: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
translation_text.mn29:2.12: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the branches and leaves, and left imagining they were heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:2.13: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
translation_text.mn29:2.21: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the branches and leaves of the spiritual life
translation_text.mn29:3.1: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness …
translation_text.mn29:3.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
translation_text.mn29:3.5: They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:3.6: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.mn29:3.7: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity.
translation_text.mn29:3.8: Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in ethics.
translation_text.mn29:3.9: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:3.10: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that:
translation_text.mn29:3.11: ‘I’m the one who is ethical, of good character. These other mendicants are unethical, of bad character.’
translation_text.mn29:3.12: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding their accomplishment in ethics. And being negligent they live in suffering.
translation_text.mn29:3.13: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, and bark, he’d cut off the shoots and leave imagining they were heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:3.14: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
translation_text.mn29:3.15: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
translation_text.mn29:3.16: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the shoots, and left imagining they were heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:3.17: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
translation_text.mn29:4.13: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the shoots of the spiritual life
translation_text.mn29:4.15: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness …
translation_text.mn29:4.18: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. …
translation_text.mn29:4.25: Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in immersion.
translation_text.mn29:4.26: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:4.27: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that:
translation_text.mn29:4.28: ‘I’m the one with immersion and unified mind. These other mendicants lack immersion, they have straying minds.’
translation_text.mn29:4.29: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. And being negligent they live in suffering.
translation_text.mn29:4.30: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood and softwood, he’d cut off the bark and leave imagining it was heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:4.31: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
translation_text.mn29:4.32: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the bark, and left imagining it was heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:4.33: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
translation_text.mn29:4.48: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the bark of the spiritual life
translation_text.mn29:5.1: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness …
translation_text.mn29:5.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity. …
translation_text.mn29:5.14: Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision.
translation_text.mn29:5.15: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:5.16: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that,
translation_text.mn29:5.17: ‘I’m the one who meditates knowing and seeing.
translation_text.mn29:5.18: These other mendicants meditate without knowing and seeing.’
translation_text.mn29:5.19: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. And being negligent they live in suffering.
translation_text.mn29:5.20: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, he’d cut out the softwood and leave imagining it was heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:5.21: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
translation_text.mn29:5.22: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
translation_text.mn29:5.23: That’s why he passed them over, cut out the softwood, and left imagining it was heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:5.24: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …
translation_text.mn29:5.42: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the softwood of the spiritual life
translation_text.mn29:6.1: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
translation_text.mn29:6.2: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn29:6.3: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
translation_text.mn29:6.4: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
translation_text.mn29:6.5: They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:6.6: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.mn29:6.7: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in ethics.
translation_text.mn29:6.8: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:6.9: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.mn29:6.10: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in ethics. Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in immersion.
translation_text.mn29:6.11: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:6.12: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.mn29:6.13: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision.
translation_text.mn29:6.14: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.
translation_text.mn29:6.15: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
translation_text.mn29:6.16: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. Being diligent, they achieve irreversible freedom.
translation_text.mn29:6.17: And it’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible freedom.
translation_text.mn29:6.18: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and leave knowing it was heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:6.19: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
translation_text.mn29:6.20: ‘This gentleman knows what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, and branches and leaves are.
translation_text.mn29:6.21: That’s why he cut out just the heartwood and left knowing it was heartwood.
translation_text.mn29:6.22: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.’ …
translation_text.mn29:6.39: It’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible freedom.
translation_text.mn29:7.1: And so, mendicants, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision.
translation_text.mn29:7.2: It is this unshakable freedom of heart
translation_text.mn29:7.3: that is the goal of the spiritual life, the core and the final end.”
translation_text.mn29:7.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn29:7.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn29:6.17: anavakāso → vijjati (sya-all) | Aṭṭhānametaṁ → ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ (sya-all, pts1ed); aṭṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ (mr)
